content.user_title: Build Payload CMS Applications with TypeScript
content.value_statement: Building Payload CMS applications requires understanding collections, fields, hooks, and access control patterns. This skill provides complete reference documentation for all Payload CMS features with practical TypeScript examples.
actual_capabilities: Configure collections with authentication, uploads, versioning, and drafts
Implement field types including relationships, blocks, arrays, and geospatial points
Create access control patterns for RBAC, multi-tenant, and row-level security
Build hooks for validation, data transformation, and side effects
Develop custom plugins with fields, hooks, endpoints, and admin components
Query data using Local API, REST, and GraphQL with proper transaction handling
limitations: Documentation only. Does not generate or scaffold new projects
Covers Payload CMS 3.x patterns. Earlier versions may differ
Code examples require a working Payload CMS installation to run
Plugin development examples require additional npm packages

output_examples.input: How do I restrict access so users only see published posts?
output: Use a read access control function that returns a query constraint
Check if user is authenticated. If yes, return true to allow all access
If no user, return a Where object: { _status: { equals: 'published' } }
This filters results at the database level for optimal performance
Add this to your collection access.read property

best_practices: Always pass req parameter to nested operations in hooks to maintain transaction atomicity
Set overrideAccess to false when passing a user to Local API to enforce their permissions
Use context flags to prevent infinite loops when hooks trigger additional operations
anti_patterns: Do not assume Local API respects access control by default. It bypasses access control unless overrideAccess is false
Do not perform nested operations in hooks without passing req. This breaks database transaction boundaries
Do not create hooks that update the same collection without context guards. This causes infinite loops

faq.question: Which databases does Payload CMS support?
faq.answer: Payload supports MongoDB, PostgreSQL, and SQLite through official database adapters. Each adapter has specific configuration options and transaction support.

faq.question: What is the maximum depth for relationship population?
faq.answer: Default depth is 2 levels. You can set maxDepth on relationship fields or pass depth parameter in queries. Higher values increase response size.

faq.question: How do I integrate Payload with my existing Next.js app?
faq.answer: Payload 3.x installs directly in your Next.js app folder. Configure payload.config.ts and add admin routes. It works alongside your existing pages.

faq.question: Is my content data kept private?
faq.answer: This skill contains only documentation. No data is collected or transmitted. Your Payload instance stores data in your configured database.

faq.question: Why are my access control rules not working in Local API?
faq.answer: Local API bypasses access control by default. Add overrideAccess: false when passing a user parameter to enforce their permissions.

faq.question: How does this compare to other CMS documentation?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on Payload CMS patterns with TypeScript examples. It covers collections, fields, hooks, access control, and plugin development.
